introduction.p: The point of this discussion is that there are nontrivial conditions on A in order for the expresion x=\text{\raisebox{1mm}{``}}\frac bA\text{\raisebox{1mm}{''}} to make sense. This condition is called invertibility.

subsection.title: Invertible Matrices
subsection.p: An inverse matrix is meant to behave like the reciprocal of a nonzero number. In order to motivate our definition, first we notice that a number a is equal to 1 if and only if ab = b for every number b: in other words, 1 is the multiplicative identity. Since I_mA = A for every m\times n matrix A, the identity matrix is the multiplicative identity: it plays the role of the number 1 in the context of matrices. Moreover, two numbers a and b are reciprocals if ab=1; therefore, two matrices A and B should be inverses if AB is the identity matrix..

statement.p: Let A be an n\times n (square) matrix. We say that A is invertible if there is an n\times n matrix B such that AB = I_n \sptxt{and} BA = I_n. In this case, the matrix B is called the inverse of A, and we write B = A\inv.
If A is not invertible, we say that it is singular.

example.p:
Let
A = \mat{2 3; 1 2} \sptxt{and} B = \mat{2 -3; -1 2}.
Verify that AB = I_2 and BA = I_2, so that A is invertible and B = A\inv.

Let
A = \mat{1 0; 0 0}.
We claim that A is singular. We will give a criterion below for invertibility; in the absence of this criterion, we simply have to verify that there is no matrix B such that AB=I_2:
\mat{1 0; 0 0}\mat{a b; c d} = \mat{a b; 0 0} \neq I_2.
Since the product of A with an arbitrary matrix B does not give the identity matrix, A is not invertible.

subsection.p: Since matrix multiplication is not commutative, it is a priori necessary to require AB=I_n and BA=I_n. However, if A and B are square matrices such that AB=I_n, then it turns out that BA=I_n automatically, so the definition given above is a bit pedantic.

bluebox.p:
If A and B are n\times n matrices then
AB = I_n \quad\iff\quad B = A\inv \quad\iff\quad BA = I_n.

subsection.p: When discussing invertible matrices, we restrict ourselves to square matrices. There is a good reason for this: if A is an m\times n matrix with m\neq n, then there does not exist an n\times m matrix B such that AB = I_m and BA = I_n. We will see why in .

statement.p:
Let A and B be invertible n\times n matrices.
Invertible matrixinverse of A\inv is invertible, and its inverse is (A\inv){}\inv = A.
Matrix multiplicationinverse of AB is invertible, and its inverse is (AB)\inv = B\inv A\inv (note the order).
Matrixtranspose ofinverse of A^T is invertible, and its inverse is (A\inv)^T.

proof.p:
In each case, showing that two matrices are inverses amounts to proving that their product is the identity matrix.
The equations AA^{-1}=I_n and A^{-1}A = I_n at the same time exhibit A^{-1} as the inverse of A and A as the inverse of A^{-1}.
We compute (B\inv A\inv)AB = B\inv(A\inv A)B = B\inv I_n B = B\inv B = I_n. Here we used the associativity of matrix multiplication and the fact that I_n B = B. This shows that B\inv A\inv is the inverse of AB.
Since the identity matrix is symmetric, we have
I_n = I_n^T = (A\inv A)^T = A^T(A\inv)^T.
This means that (A\inv)^T is the inverse of A^T.

remark.p: It is rarely true that (AB)\inv = A\inv B\inv. If we try to multiply AB by A\inv B\inv as in the proof of the second above, we get: (AB)(A\inv B\inv) = A(BA\inv)B\inv. In this case, there is no cancellation because we cannot change the order of the terms in the product.

More concretely, let A = \mat{2 3; 1 2} \sptxt{and} B = \mat{2 1; 3 2} = A^T. According to this and the third above, we have
B\inv = (A^T)\inv = (A\inv)^T = \mat{2 -3; -1 2}^T = \mat{2 -1; -3 2}.
Then we compute
A\inv B\inv = \mat{2 -3; -1 2}\mat{2 -1; -3 2} = \mat{13 -8; -8 5}.
On the other hand, we have
AB = \mat{13 8; 8 5},
so
AB(A\inv B\inv) = \mat{13 8; 8 5}\mat{13 -8; -8 5} = \mat{105 -64; 64 -39}\neq \mat{1 0; 0 1}.
It follows that A\inv B\inv is not the inverse of AB. Indeed,
(AB)\inv = B\inv A\inv = \mat{2 -1; -3 2}\mat{2 -3; -1 2} = \mat{5 -8; -8 13}.

subsection.p:
Recall from the matrix algebra caveats that matrix multiplication is not cancelative: that is, AB=AC does not generally imply B=C. However, if A is invertible then we can multiply both sides on the left by A\inv to obtain:
AB = AC \quad\implies\quad A\inv(AB) = A\inv(AC) \quad\implies\quad I_nB = I_nC \quad\implies\quad B = C.
Multiplying on the right by A\inv shows that BA=CA implies B=C.

bluebox.title: Cancelativity for Invertible Matrices

subsection.p: The following is our first (of many) useful criteria for a matrix to be invertible. It says that one can check invertibility using Gaussian elimination: it is not necessary to evaluate AB for an arbitrary matrix B, as we did in this .

statement.p:
Let A be an n\times n matrix. The following are equivalent:
A is invertible.
The reduced row echelon form of A is the identity matrix I_n.
A has rank n: i.e., it has a pivot in each row and each column.

subsection.p: We will prove this theorem when we discuss elementary matrices below. In terms of systems of equations, it is important to think of the matrix A in this theorem as the coefficient matrix: after all, we are trying to solve Ax=b by dividing by A.

bluebox.p: The phrase the following are equivalent means that, for a given matrix A, either all of the properties are true, or all of them are false: it is not possible for one to be true and the others to be false.

example.p:
Consider the matrix and its row echelon form from this :
\mat{2 3; 1 2} \quad\xrightarrow{\text{REF}}\quad \mat{\color{seq-red}2 3; 0 \color{seq-red}1/2}.
This matrix has two pivots, one in each row and each column, so it is invertible according to the third property in the criterion.

subsection.p: We now come to the issue of how to compute an inverse matrix. This turns out to be a GaussJordan calculation.

statement.p: The input is an n\times n matrix A, and the output is the inverse matrix A\inv, or not invertible.

ol.li: Form the augmented matrix \amat{A I_n}, the n\times 2n augmented matrix with the n\times n identity matrix on the right half.
Perform Gaussian elimination on \amat{A I_n}. If there is a pivot to the right of the augmentation line, the matrix is not invertible.
Otherwise, perform Jordan substitution on the result of the previous step. The reduced row echelon form of \amat{A I_n} has the form \amat{I_n B}, and B = A\inv.

subsection.p: We will prove this theorem in below.

statement.p: Determine if the matrix A = \mat{1 0 4; 0 1 2; 0 -3 -4}, is invertible, and if so, find its inverse.
Determine if the matrix A = \mat{1 0 4; 0 1 2; 0 -3 -6}. is invertible, and if so, find its inverse.

subsection.p: There is a shortcut for finding the inverse of a 2\times 2 matrix. This only works on 2\times 2 matrices; there is a version for larger matrices, but it is not a shortcut.

statement.p:
Let A = \mat{a b; c d}.
If ad-bc \neq 0, then A is invertible, and A\inv = \frac 1{ad-bc}\mat{d -b; -c a}.
If ad-bc = 0, then A is not invertible.

ol.li:
Suppose that ad-bc\neq 0. Define \displaystyle B = \frac 1{ad-bc}\mat{d -b; -c a}.
Then
AB = \mat{a b; c d}\frac 1{ad-bc}\mat{d -b; -c a} = \frac 1{ad-bc}\mat[c]{ad-bc 0; 0 ad-bc} = I_2.
This means that A is invertible and B=A\inv.

Suppose now that ad-bc=0. Define B = \mat{d -b; -c a}. Then AB = \mat{a b; c d}\mat{d -b; -c a} = \mat[c]{ad-bc 0; 0 ad-bc} = 0. If A were invertible then we could multiply both sides of this equation by A\inv to obtain 0 = A\inv0 = A\inv(AB) = (A\inv A)B = I_2B = B, which means B=0, and hence d=0,\,-b=0,\,-c=0,\,a=0. But this implies A=0, and the zero matrix is not invertible (it has no pivots). Hence A could not have been invertible.

answer.p:
Here we have a=2,\,b=3,\,c=1, and d=2, so ad-bc=4-3=1. Hence
A\inv = \frac 1{ad-bc}\mat{d -b; -c a} = \mat{2 -3; -1 2}.

bluebox.p: If A is invertible, then Ax = b \quad\iff\quad x = A\inv b.

subsection.p: The expression x = A\inv b is in fact a linear formula for the coordinates of x in terms of the coordinates of b. This makes it easy to solve Ax=b for multiple values of b given A\inv.

answer.p:
We rewrite this system as Ax=b for A = \mat{2 3; 1 2} \qquad b = \vec{b_1 b_2}. We saw in this that A\inv = \mat{2 -3; -1 2}, so that
\vec{x_1 x_2} = A\inv\vec{b_1 b_2} = \mat{2 -3; -1 2}\vec{b_1 b_2} = \vec{2b_1-3b_2 -b_1+2b_2}.
Hence the solution is x_1 = 2b_1-3b_2 and x_2 = -b_1 + 2b_2.
